A.O.D.I.T




Account
On
Details with

Triggers



This system helps with memories.
Its Finding a way for memories to occur.
So, when you are studying about Chemicals, and you had to remember the element with the atomic number. Such as let's say Gold, and you remember Au for the element, but don't remember the Number.

The best way for you to remember, is with a physical trigger that can cause the memory of the number to occur.

Such as: Clap, snapping you fingers, Pound on something, or even a gesture.
As long as you can create a function that will trigger the memory.

Now, for individual triggers that is meant for numerous amounts of things to remember, like you remember How the first World War started, but you cant remember the exact name of the person who died, who the shooter was, and the how US was Brought into it.. And it's not a multi choice so it's not Gunna be easy to Know without the name popping up in front of you.

Away to remember all of this is by a visual aspect of the name, not the memory of the name.

Take a thin piece of papier and write down Gavtilo Princip.


Now hold it to your phone, now take the light of the phone an pass it by once or twice, and i Don't mean turning on you flashlight of the phone on and off, i mean waive the screen light of the phone behind a few times. No, in all seriousness, if you at least remember three letters of Gavril Princip and remember a color or a part of a Picture that was on your phone through your papier, then this will trigger a quick flash in you head what of "Not the Exact Name" that is Gravil Proncip, But a name that looks like Gravil Princip. how to not cramping 10 subjects two days before an exam
🙂

1. Study for short amounts of time consistently
a. Brain is better at encoding information using repeated sessions

2. Establish routine study sessions
a. Helps prime brain for learning
b. Becomes easier to learn during the dedicated time slot

3. Use flash cards
a. Excellent memory reinforcement tool
b. Accessible and flexible

4. Have a specific goal for each study session
a. Focuses your mind on understanding a key concept

5. Study with the mindset of needing to teach the content
a. Brain organises the information in a more logical and coherent structure

6. Practise is key, especially in a way that facilitates feedback
a. Practise trains your brain to get used to the environment
b. Tests help identify gaps in your knowledge
c. Testing increases confidence which leads to better performance

7. Have a designated, set-apart place to study with all the equipment you need
a. Primes your brain for studying

8. Listen to classical music or nothing
a. Rhythmic background noise hinders focus

9. Get rid of distractions (eg. phone)
a. Interruptions severely decrease concentration

I condensed the video for you :D

1. Study in small short chunks (eg 20 mins each day)

2.Get Sleep and set specific time for studying (eg set revision time to 3-4pm)

3. Don’t passively read notes/books as it’s proven ineffective (use flashcards instead)

4. Aim for specific goals/section the revision (eg science equations only)

5. Teaching what you’re revising is proven more effective

6. Practice the topics over and do past exam papers

7. Have a designated spot with all the materials needed to prime your brain for revision (eg have revision books and equipment needed)

8. Don’t listen to music while revising as it’s proven ineffective

9. Put away your phone/distractions for focused revision sessions

No one has succeeded acing any exam but by cheating. There are two ways by which people cheat on exams. They use helping tools when it´s not allowed, or the teacher shows them the right answers to the exam questions before other students are shown the same questions. Why can´t we ace an exam? Simple. Exams are not designed to be aced. They are carefully designed not to. Each teacher designs their exams on one principle and one principle only - the principle that the exam questions must never focus solely on the material taught in the curriculum. This is why exams in British history focus on Henry VIII and Andy Warhol, not on how to live in Britain. The first exam which will be based on the curriculum´s material will never air. But there is a solution to this problem. That solution is banning exams altogether. Ban exams, ban grading. When you ban exams and grades, you give students the opportunity to go to school to learn to learn. For that to happen, you must separate classroom and teacher. The dangerous and life threatening deleterious delusion of grandeur that there are students who can easily ace exams by watching a youtube video has resulted in nothing but millions of unemployed students. This tells us that all exams promote only three things - a - unemployment, b - drugs, and c - prostitution. The question then is - how are people hired for work? Job skills. You don´t earn those by going to college or by finishing school. You earn those by going to the job centers, learning the job, and making sure the staff superior does not discriminate against you. Our patience for exams is over. Exams are ancient history. We are on the internet now, which has practically killed off whatever remained of the exam grading system. Therefore, if we bye bye the exam grading system, we are putting jobs back in business, and removing pointless obstacles which don´t teach anybody anything.

I'm in the physical therapy program and what seems to help me is.

1) taking my PowerPoint with me to class so I can circle, dash, jot notes down as he emphasizes.

2) studying at the house for twenty minutes, relaxed. 5 minute break ( to text etc ) another twenty minutes and on. Because anyone can study without irritation for twenty minutes.

3) as I read a chapter I make flash cards in order to the chapter. I write "c" next to the ideas and concepts I'm creating a "c"ard for. Then when I read the chapter again. I finish a page then if it had 6 C's, I pick up the first 6 cards and test my knowledge on that page.

Hope it helps

9. Eliminate distractions

One of the most important things for memorizing and understanding is a hormone called Growth hormone. This hormone secreted by pituitary gland, which is in the brain. When Brain is resting at night and is in a slow-wave part of the sleep, can order the gland for Growth hormone. 70% of our growth hormone secreted at a special time of our sleep during night (that brain is resting and has a slow wave), and that time is between 10 pm to 2 am. That is why when u are awake at this time and u are studying, u cannot memorize things very well, because u don't have the Growth hormone that u need for memorizing. Growth hormone also is important for other part of our life.... So better to sleep early.

+AsapSCIENCE About the ideal study session length, is it in anyway related to the attention span? And is attention span something fixed or something you can increase or decrease? Is the ideal study session different for each individual or is there a general pattern or is everyone the same? And does the ideal study session length increase if the activity is to your liking, primed to your brain already? I applied the 90 minutes work 20 minutes break work plan from the ASAP Science video on productivity for a few months and found that the short time does not make me feel engaged as well as long sessions and when busy schedules forced me to stop taking breaks and just work until it's finished or else, I feel better work is done. I feel that if I break things up into many sessions I have to reintegrate myself to the task while if I do long sessions I feel I get more and more entrenched. __[[ Turning into Digital Goldfish, BBC News / Is Technology and the Internet Reducing Pupil's Attention Spans, The Guardian / City Living 'Makes It Harder to Concentrate', BBC News / You Now Have a Shorter Attention Span Than a Goldfish / Time. ]]__

wish they put a summary of all the 9 things haha.

1: don't cram or do all nighters; break up study sessions in little bits
2: utilize flash cards over reading for details (might stuff your brain w/ unimportant stuff)
3: have a goal for each study session
4: utilize practice tests - they help w/ confidence (kind of a no-brainer imo)
5: learn with the goal to teach; helps brain organize information you're learning
6: have a designated time/schedule to study (primes brain)
7: have a sacred study location w/ all the tools you'd normally need (helps w/ priming the brain)
8: don't listen to rhythmic music (probably not any music)
9: put away your phone

Great video.  My only quibble is that not all people are better at learning in small chunks.  Our education system is based on that supposition, but it doesn't work very well for people with ADD, for instance.  Counterintuitively perhaps, big chunks are better for them.   From personal experience, university was much easier than high school because the information came in larger doses, which made seeing the 'big picture' easier.  High school programs tend to ruminate on 10 minutes worth of information for an hour, which makes maintaining focus difficult to impossible for some.  I don't know what, if any, difference that makes for studying, but it's worth pointing out that we don't all process information the same way.

I have to disagree with number 3. Being an avid reader I always high light pages, dog ear pages (fold page over), underline good sections, cross out dumb sections, etc. Perhaps if someone else tells you to highlight everything in a book it could be negative. Imagine this though: You read a book and highlight all the things that impacted you or got you to truly think, you dog ear certain pages that act as a highlight for the whole page. Then you're refreshing on a subject, but you don't have time to reread the entire book, so what do you do? You reread the pages you marked up. It's essentially the same as flash cards which were praised so highly right after or they can work as cliff notes. But aside from that, the video was great and I appreciate the upload, so thanks!

I never once studied all throughout school, in a systematic way at least. I never sat down to study anything in particular and and I never took any notes in class. However, I consistently aced every test put in front of me. I'm not bragging, but I am extremely curious why such an underachiever as myself got through school basically passing classes on test and quiz grades alone, while others were doing hours of homework and studying a day but seemingly having a lesser understanding of the subjects as I.  My "method" in school was basically to sit next to friends and talk about video games and joke around a lot. I would listen to the teachers' lessons and I would answer all the questions the teachers asked to myself. I think I subconsciously tried to obtain a fundamental understanding of the subjects in my mind instead of trying to force blunt memorization. I would also "teach" myself the material by thinking to myself as if I was talking to myself, trying to explain things to myself in the simplest manner possible. I just find it fascinating how differently different peoples' brains work and how much of an impact it has on behavior and personality and abilities, yet we're all so very similar.

In case you forgot most of the video's key points or don't want to watch the whole thing:
1. Break up your study times into 30-minute increments
2. Study at specific times on specific days
3. Use flashcards; not highlights
4. Focus on one task at a time, like how to balance chemical equations
5. Learn to teach, rather than to test; study like you're planning to explain it to someone else
6. Take practice tests and learn from your mistakes
7. Study in specific areas and don't do anything else besides studying there
8. Don't listen to music even "study" music while studying
9. Put away your phone -in case this wasn't obvious

Highlighting actually is one of the things that works the best for me. But I never highlight in the book. I would extract information as I read the text and would put it all on unlined white paper. (because there is no paper with lines small enough to how I write) and also allows me to shift my information in different areas, especially when creating tables and graphs. This organization helps to organize my own brain to how I see it rather than how the book does.

I use color pens to write different things given to what topic they are and place the course number, class and page number at the top right corner.

Topics such as "conditioning and learning" goes in green while the term conditioning or "priming" goes in blue.
Further definitions are written in light blue. Comment with // before in green.
Names of people in pink
Black for all definitions and concepts
Red for any major key concepts
purple for any sub topics.

This works quite well and like note cards, helps to break things up in color so it forms new associations. Especially when I try to remember names of people.

Also I agree that routine and short times in study is help full but so is sleep as well. Rest too. Long study times isn't the biggest issues but it is the pacing and not enough breaks that leaves the brain over worked. For every 30 or so mins I take 5 on a break. Get up, stretch. And get something to eat or drink. I even sometimes would go out to get a treat before my study time and leave it somewhere so when I am done with one subject I reward myself and go to the next. This reward system also helps condition the brain.

Repeated actions and associations are also big key factors. Like the place to which you study as is why you need your own "spot" you will remember more in the same setting than if you were removed from it. Which is why I recommend to take tests in the class rooms rather than a testing center (for many reasons) because it removes you from the environment which you first received that information.

Music on the other hand is one thing I love as well but depending on what it is, over rhythmic music can be more harm than good but music that is soothing can be help full, at least for me as it isn't repetitive (which can make you feel more tired such as a fan blowing in the background) or too distracting. IF anything by creating sound it helps cut back a few more sounds that can be a distraction. Like others talking in the room.

And I know everyone that this might be the"digital Age" But really, put down your phones. Johnny from across the street isn't going to help you get better grades when you are flirting with him all night instead of studying for your exams.

1. Multiple 30 minute sessions as oppose to one 3 hour session will help your brain process dat info and make studying progressively easier.

2. Set up specific times during the day and week to study so yo brain can get used to thinking around those times.

3. Flash cards are a very dandy tool--especially for studying on the go.

4. Set specific goals for each study session to ensure you're not aimlessly studying.

5. Make sure you're able to teach it to someone successfully.

6. PRACTICE like an effing BOSS. Remember, the actually sitting down for the first time and opening your textbook is the hardest part.

7. Find yourself a designated place of study with supplies at the ready.

8. Don't listen to music. 😢 I know, but either don't listen to it or make it a smooth, calm instrumental.

9. Put. Away. Your phone. If you use it for easy access to Google or something turn off those notifications and fight the urge for a "five minute IG check." Best thing to do would be avoid your phone completely unless you're like me and can be in the same room as it without freaking out over every notification.

I disagree. I have always had high grades and I never study like that. I do my homework and try to understand what I write on my notebook. I ask many questions until feel that I understand everything. Then, before the day of the test, I read what I need at night. Reading my notes are the last thing I do before going to bed, and at the next day, I have all the information in my brain. Personally, I was a little disappointed by this video because not everyone learn or should study the same as other people. It depends on their personalities. If you are always moving in your chair or making draws on your notebook while your professor is explaining the topic, it means that you should study by writing and practicing a lot. Now, if you feel the necessity of always being looking at the board, it means that you should study by using visual tips. For example, use yellow paper and red marker. Why? Because red is a color that is very bright and do not confuse your brain. That's why it is easier to read an old yellow book than a new one since the mix of black and white confuses your brain making you feel tired. Finally, if you prefer to listen to what your professor says, you should study by repeating the information with loud voice or recording yourself and then listen to it.
If you are visual, don't try to use the same study method of a person who prefers to listen...that's why some people learn faster than you even though you use the same study method because they know how to study and probably their style is not the best one for you.

I use fluorescent markers (yellow and orange) when studying, and it helps me tremendously. However, I only mark the key concepts and words, usually 1-4 words in one mark. This way I have 5-8 marks on one page, which I think is optimal. I use yellow for more important words, and orange for less important. I also mix them up, mark with yellow then put thin orange border and the other way around. I think it really helps. I NEVER mark entire sentences, and I stopped using pens to underline, a long time ago. Enjoy.

Practice tests actually work really well! I had a teacher in college who would give us little quizzes, and then maybe 4 tests during each semester. I always did really well in his classes because most of the things in the tests were already covered in the quizzes.
Another trick in the hat method. Write down questions, or words you need to define on slips of paper. Then write the answer on the other side. Fold the paper so the question is on the outside, then put them all into a hat. Then take a piece out, read the question, and try to answer it. If you're correct, leave the paper out. If you are wrong, it goes back into the hat. You are done studying once all the pieces of paper are out of the hat. I would usually do at least 2-3 rounds of this, until I could answer them all on the first try. Then I would come back to it the next day to see if I remembered.

I never understood why notes are still a thing teachers make you write down. People don't seem to understand that critical thinking is far more important than writing down what your teacher thinks you'll understand. If students take notes in a classroom, they shouldn't write it down word for word, or they won't understand it. They need to put it in their own words, and if they can't do that effectively, they need to either ask the teacher or learn about it on their own time.
